Docker tip: always add `restart: unless-stopped` to every service in your docker-compose.yml. Your apps come back automatically after a reboot or crash. Only stops if you explicitly `docker compose stop`.

Self-hosting tip: always use named Docker volumes instead of bind mounts for database containers. Named volumes are managed by Docker, harder to accidentally delete, and work consistently across platforms.

```yaml
volumes:
  db_data:

services:
  postgres:
    volumes:
      - db_data:/var/lib/postgresql/data
```

#selfhosted #docker #homelab #foss #linux #tips

Self-hosting cost math: Google One 2TB ($100/yr) + iCloud 200GB ($36/yr) + 1Password family ($60/yr) = $196/year. A used mini PC costs $150-200 once, plus ~$25/year in electricity. Pays for itself in year one.

Quick Docker networking tip: containers on the same Docker Compose network can reach each other by service name. No need to use IP addresses. `http://postgres:5432` just works from any container in the same stack.

Self-hosting security tip: never expose Docker ports directly to the internet. Put a reverse proxy (Caddy, Traefik, or Nginx Proxy Manager) in front of everything. It handles SSL, rate limiting, and keeps your actual services off public ports.

#selfhosted #security #docker #reverseproxy #homelab #foss #linux #opensource
Docker tip: use `docker compose logs -f --tail 50 servicename` to follow logs for a specific service without getting buried in history. The --tail flag saves your sanity on busy stacks.

Networking tip: if you're self-hosting behind a home router, set a static IP for your server via DHCP reservation (not in /etc/netplan). Router reboots won't change your server's address and port forwarding rules stay intact.

Before upgrading any self-hosted app, always pull the new image without bringing down the old one first:

```
docker compose pull
docker compose up -d
```

This way the download happens while your service is still running. Downtime = just the container restart, not the image download.

#selfhosted #docker #homelab #tips #foss #linux #opensource
The 3-2-1 backup rule applies to self-hosting too: 3 copies of your data, on 2 different types of media, with 1 stored offsite. Restic + a cheap B2 bucket covers the offsite copy for pennies.

Self-hosting cost reality check: a family of four on Google One + iCloud + 1Password spends $300-500/year in subscriptions. A $200 mini PC replaces all of them. After year one, you're saving money every month.

Watchtower vs Diun — two approaches to Docker image updates:

Watchtower: automatically pulls and restarts containers (dangerous for production)
Diun: just notifies you when updates are available

For self-hosting, Diun is the safer choice. You should always read release notes before upgrading.

#selfhosted #docker #homelab #foss #linux #opensource #containers
Quick env var tip: never put secrets directly in docker-compose.yml. Use a .env file in the same directory and reference variables with ${VARIABLE_NAME}. Keep .env out of version control.

Docker volume backup one-liner:

docker run --rm -v myvolume:/source -v $(pwd):/backup alpine tar czf /backup/myvolume.tar.gz -C /source .

Works for any named volume. Schedule it with cron. #docker #selfhosted

If your self-hosted app is slow, check if you're running the database on the same disk as the app data. Splitting the DB onto a separate SSD (or at least a separate partition) can dramatically improve I/O performance, especially for Nextcloud and Immich.
